qas.question: How did the Prussian army perform in 1759/
How would one characterize the encounter with the Russian army in 1757?

answers.text: the Hanoverians defeated an army of 60,000 French

qas.question: What was the result of the Battle of Maxen?

answers.text: Austrian general Daun forced the surrender of an entire Prussian corps of 13,000

qas.question: What happened to Frederick's army at the Battle at Kunersdorf?

answers.text: Frederick himself lost half his army

context: The year <a0_0>1759 saw several Prussian defeats<a0_0/>. At the Battle of Kay, or Paltzig, the Russian Count Saltykov with <a1_0>47,000 Russians defeated 26,000 Prussians<a1_0/> commanded by General Carl Heinrich von Wedel. Though <a2_0>the Hanoverians defeated an army of 60,000 French<a2_0/> at Minden, <a3_0>Austrian general Daun forced the surrender of an entire Prussian corps of 13,000<a3_0/> in the Battle of Maxen. <a4_0>Frederick himself lost half his army<a4_0/> in the Battle of Kunersdorf (now Kunowice Poland), the worst defeat in his military career and one that drove him to the brink of abdication and thoughts of suicide. The disaster resulted partly from his misjudgment of the Russians, who had already demonstrated their strength at Zorndorf and at Gross-Jägersdorf (now Motornoye, Russia), and partly from good cooperation between the Russian and Austrian forces.
